page.title: 02NATURE.BURGHILL/CREDENHILL
page.content: An area of well cultivated red clay supporting a variety of flora and fauna. Bounded by rising ground wooded with conifers to the South West and a higher belt of deciduous trees to the North. The commonest mammals are rabbits. Voles,shrews and mice provide food for kestrels and little owls. Most years a pair of buzzards nest in the area. Foxes are numerous and badgers can sometimes be seen at dusk Several small ponds provide food for visiting herons.Hedgerow flowers are abundant - in Spring primroses and violets and grass verges are golden with celandines. Some cowslips occur and more rarely sweet woodruff. Ladies smock grows with large colonies of stitchwort and hedge parsleys.In Summer 65 varieties of birds have been counted and several types of bats fly by night.
